dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAPTION: Belfast, the Fifties A beautiful ordered garden. The colours are fairy-tale bright. Bird song. On a window an election poster has been taped: VOTE HOOLE

dialogues.speaker: FOR A GENUINE ALTERNATIVE
dialogues.text: On the grass sits a portable record player. Beside it a small pile of records. CHILD TERRI’S hands pick up ‘I Saw the Light’ - Hank Williams in his trademark rhinestone su - and places it on the turntable A needle is set down on the vinyl. CHILD TERRI smiles, enraptured. A tomato bursts against the window, obliterating the poster. CHILD TERRI dives for cover behind a large shrub. An egg follows the tomato; stones land in the garden alon with arrows from a kid’s bow. The TWO BOYS doing the throwing and shooting are under ten. BOY 1 wears a tatty sheriff's hat, BOY 2 has ‘war paint’ on his face.

dialogues.speaker: BOY 1
dialogues.text: Fenian Lovers. An arrow flies overhead. In the shrub CHILD TERRI crouche holding on to his head: he knows he has to keep it down. BOY 2 prepares to unleash a final arrow.

dialogues.speaker: BOY 1, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Commie bastards. The shrub seems to vibrate with rage. CHILD TERRI pops up

dialogues.speaker: CHILD TERRI
dialogues.text: My da’s not a communist, he’s a socialist. His eye widens as the arrow speeds towards it. Impact. INT. TERRI’S WORLD - NIGHT AND DAY JUMBLED TOGETHER The music is distorted, becoming the soundtrack as the arrow takes us on an accelerated journey into Terri’s world, and through the future, private and public.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think is he going to lose it? There are looming faces - DOCTOR, Terri’s parents MAVIS a GEORGE - a disorienting rush of lights - suggestive of ey tests, but merging with other lights - city lights, searchlights. There are eye charts, which merge with 60s protest placards - US out of Vietnam - Ban the Bomb - wit magazine covers: Ego, OZ MAVIS (CONT’D) Is he going to lose it? The charts, placards, magazines merge with newspaper headlines charting the start of the Northern Irish Troubles, a barrage of surreal images from the 50s to the 70s darker as the headlines change: from agricultural sho to sheep fleeing a bomb blast, from schoolkids dancing at fete to a line of monks being frisked by British soldiers MAVIS (0.S.) (CONT’D) (growing frantic) Is he going to be blinded? Image and sound reach a crescendo.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (consoling) He’s just going to see things a little bit differently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An explosion fills the TV screen. TERRI, now in his 20s, rubs his eye. There is, throughout an open, almost child-like quality to his expression totally at odds with some of what he does, and says. Beside him sit MAVIS and GEORGE, a man whose bearing, as much as his waistcoat and collarless shirt, marks him as out of his time.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: What a fucking nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Mind you your language.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And they call this a revolution? A poster is on the wall VOTE HOOLEY STILL A GENUINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI wears a Kodak overall. Sitting on a work bench, kne up, smoking a joint is his mate ERIC - more sixth Stone than fifth Beatle, more Sticky Finger than Satisfaction. There are photos pegged up to dry. There are also flyers (clearly home-made): Terri Hooley, Tonight at 8... Max Romeo’s ‘War ina Babylon’ plays on a portable turntable. TERRI sings along as he pegs up another flyer.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: ‘War ina Babylon, tribal war ina Babylon, let me tell you, it sipple out there...’

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Sssh.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Do you hear something? The ‘something’ is an alarm going off, but it barely registers before TERRI starts singing again.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: ‘,.. tribal was ina Babylon...’ (breaking off) What baffles me, Jamaica and Belfast have so much in common. Cops and soldiers giving you grief day in day out, armed gangs running round murdering people for fuck all. But at least in Jamaica they have decent music. A muffled thump. TERRI and ERIC look at the door. ERIC nicks the joint; waves smoke away. TERRI opens door and i face to face with a BOMB DISPOSAL MAN, or bomb disposal blimp as he appears.

dialogues.speaker: BOMB DISPOSAL MAN
dialogues.text: (indistinctly) Get the fuck out! ERIC jumps down from the bench. TERRI carefully takes the record off before leaving. A second later he returns, gra a handful of flyers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLDIERS herd OTHER WORKERS behind a cordon where news cameras lurk. TERRI and ERIC saunter out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are you coming down tonight?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: You know me, I’ll go anywhere where there are people, ergo....

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Jesus, everyone's a defeatist.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Here, just to cheer you up. He passes TERRI a bag of grass.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Tell you the truth, I’m a bit skint at the minute.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (brushing it off) Mates rates. TERRI spies TWO WOMEN IN KODAK OVERALLS; ERIC spies a YOU BRITISH SOLDIER standing a little apart from the others

dialogues.speaker: TERRI AND ERIC
dialogues.text: Catch you later. They go off in opposite directions, TERRI to the women.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: The future Mrs Hooley.

dialogues.speaker: KODAK WOMAN 1
dialogues.text: Which one of us?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Either of you, both He hands them a flyer.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come down to this tonight.

dialogues.speaker: KODAK WOMAN 1
dialogues.text: In town? Have you a death wish? She and her friend walk off giggling.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (after them, arms spread) I have a life wish. He turns. MARTY heavy beard, heavy coat, heavy politics, approaches, red-headed NED skulking in his wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty. Ned.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I’d watch where I shouted that life-wish stuff. Some people might take it as a challenge.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (nods to Kodak building) Some people look like they have enough to keep them busy.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: That’s not one of ours. If it had been one of ours there wouldn’t have been a warning. He flicks the CND badge on TERRI’s coat. MARTY (CONT’D) I’d forgotten about those.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Does it not get lonely being the last man standing? MARTY glances up, sees ERIC passing something to YOUNG BRITISH SOLDIER, who slips him a banknote in exchange. TERRI sees MARTY seeing it. He flourishes a flyer an inch from MARTY’s face.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Do your feet a favour, take them out dancing, like you used to. MARTY balls up the flyer, shoves it back in TERRI’s face.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: See you around. He and NED move off. TERRI has contrived to stick flyers their back.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (under his breath) I fucking hope not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deserted, but for TERRI, walking. He stops at length befo a metal cage protecting the front of a bar: the Harp.  6. A security camera tracks his approach. TERRI takes out hi glass eye and thrusts it up to the lens. A buzzer sounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hand that held up the eye now rifles through a box of records: Shangri-las, 13th Floor Elevators, Gladiators. A poster on the wall reads TERRI HOOLEY BELFAST’S NO.1 DJ. Next to it a WAR IS OVER poster (‘Love John and Yoko’), another for the Rolling Stones gig at the Ulster Hall, 19 an outlaws gallery: Hank Williams, Bob Marley, Johnny Cas TERRI downs a brandy, lights a cigarette lit, takes a record from its sleeve: ‘Soul Rebel’ by The Wailers. He places it on the turntable, closes his eyes and starts to sing along.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I'm a rebel, soul rebel He opens his eyes. He is brought back to earth. The room empty save for PAT, the Harp’s Manager (he has one of tho Belfast expressions of permanent doubt: Two plus two? Is four?) and an OLD BOY at the bar doing Spot the Ball. PAT shakes his head slowly, approaches TERRI.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: (handing TERRI £5) Here.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I thought we said ten?

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Ten for the whole night. That’s you finished, I’m pulling the plug. In fact you needn’t bother coming back.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Why? Look around you. It’s finished. No one wants to come out any more.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: She does. A young woman has appeared out of nowhere and is dancing hypnotically alone in the centre of the floor.  This is RUTH. There is something handmade about her; a style so individual it borders on the eccentric. PAT hands TERRI another £5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH orders a drink. A loud scratch as, mid-song, TERRI changes tack. Dion, ‘Born to be with you’. The OLD BOY looks round, confused. TERRI skips down from the stage. RUTH is putting change in her purse.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Are you here on your own?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I was out for a walk and heard the music. Thought I’d come in and see if it was as lively as it sounded. The OLD BOY sneezes. TERRI and RUTH look at him, then at each other, then laugh.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: It wasn’t always like this, there were nights here when you had to queue just to get on the guest list.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I don’t mean to be cheeky, but you don’t look like a man with that many friends.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Do you want to know the truth of it? I used to have lots of friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI and RUTH are surrounded by the very FRIENDS Terri i invoking: swaying to music, laughing, animated. In the middle of the floor three men clink shorts glasses: MARTY less heavy (and wearing a CND badge); NED, and ANDY, with Zapata moustache.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Lots of anarchist friends, and Marxist friends, and socialist friends, and pacifist friends, and feminist friends, and friends who were fuck all.  10 MARTY, NED and ANDY down their drinks. NED’s comes back u his nose. The others laugh, pat his back. NED is furious.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then the first shot was fired The three shorts glasses smash.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And the first bomb exploded and suddenly I didn’t have any more Marxist, or feminist, or anarchist friends. The room darkens. The FRIENDS are now on opposing sides o the room, MARTY and NED on one side side, ANDY on the other. There is finger-pointing, rancour.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just had Catholic friends and Protestant friends. And I don’t consider myself either. So...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 Back to the 70s. The room is empty again save for TERRI a RUTH, the PAT and the OLD BOY.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: So now nobody likes you?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Now I’m just a bit more choosy about my friends. Anyway, you’re one to talk, where’s your gang?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: They don’t like dancing as much as I do. TERRI reaches over behind the bar for a note pad.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Have you a pen?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I’m an English student, it’s compulsory.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Here, stick your name at the top. RUTH hesitates, shrugs, writes.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (squinting at the page) Are you Martian?  11 12 13 14

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Stop it. It’s Ruth. R-U-T-H

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Well, R-U-T-H, congratulations, you're the first name on my new guest list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH pushes TERRI up against the wire grille over a shop window bearing the sign CLOSING DOWN: EVERYTHING MUST GO.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (up for air) Do you want to go back to my mum and dad’s?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: No. Do you want to go back to my mum and dad’s?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH is practically trailing TERRI by the hand. INT. DAVE AND MARILYN’S HOUSE - NIGHT 13 An ancient species of Mimeograph machine sits on a table. MARILYN HYNDMAN - a few years older than Ruth - leans against the wall, smoking, while DAVE HYNDMAN circles it, wrench in his hand, trying to decide which bit to hit. RUTH drags TERRI through, tossing out perfunctory introductions

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Dave, Marilyn: Terri. Terri: Dave, Marilyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The yard has room only for a bin, a bicycle, TERRI and RUTH.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I was at a party here one night, it was all getting a bit much, so I came out here and hid.  15 10.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Where? He follows the line of RUTH’s gaze: the bin.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re not serious. He walks over, lifts the lid, looks inside, then turns to RUTH.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shall we? Hand in hand they each put one leg over then the other, disappearing as though in a variety show magic act. One hand reappears and replaces the bin lid. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’ve got a glass eye.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So shut it.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Remind me to tell you my John Lennon story some time.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shut it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wedding picture on the hall wall: Terri and Ruth. Bags and boxes the length of the hallway. TERRI and RUTH are moving in. DAVE comes in through the front door carrying a large carton. TERRI, behind him, carries an ashtray, into which every so often as he rants he flicks ash.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I tell you another thing I hate, that word communities. Whenever anybody in Northern Ireland says community what they’re really saying is side

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (from behind the box) You're dead right, it’s false consciousness.  11.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Whereas collective....

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: «+. people of all religions and none working to a common end...

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Mind your feet there, Dave. TERRI bends to set his ashtray on the floor. When he stan ERIC has appeared in the front doorway, looking self- conscious, as well he might under a white cowboy hat. TER does an exaggerated double take.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't tell me, it’s Hank Williams's birthday? Roy Rogers’? Desperate Dan’s? ERIC is unable to get a word in before RUTH passes.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Nice hat, Eric. ERIC gives up. MARILYN comes into the hallway. She stops a pile of boxes and reads what’s written on the side.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Terri, Terri, Terri, Terri... (bends to see last one) Terri. She looks around, sees TERRI.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are these all your clothes?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (points to a black bag on the floor) These are my clothes. (points to the boxes) These are my records.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (lifts a box) Where do you want them?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Back bedroom for now. TERRI stands on the doorstep and lights another cigarette ERIC joins him.  12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A For Sale sign is now marked Sold.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Listen, I came to tell you, I’m clearing off to London for a while.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Don’t take it so hard, you’re still special. Eric tries to raise a smile without success. He looks ove his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I got lifted the other night. The scene behind ERIC darkens. He isn’t standing on the doorstep any more, but on a stool, naked and shivering, h hands covering his groin. HOODED MEN stand around him. ERIC, however, continues to talk as though to TERRI.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A couple of our old anti-war pals were there.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: That fucker Marty?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: The other crowd. ANDY whips off his mask with one hand, to reveal a leaner infinitely meaner-looking version of his 60s self; with t other hand he brandishes a pair of sheep shears.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Except of course they’re all a bit more pro-war these days. The other HOODED MEN hold shears too now. They advance on ERIC. TERRI winces as the shears flash and snap. One by one the HOODED MEN step back; ANDY is last to go. ERIC is on the doorstep once more. His hand shakes as he takes off the hat. His hair has bee savaged.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Fuck me.  17 18 13.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Told me I was lucky it wasn't a bullet.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: For what, dealing a bit of blow? ERIC leans in and takes hold of TERRI’S wrist.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: It’s not the drugs. It’s me, it’s you - they try to pass themselves off as the school rebels, we show them up as the prefects. He puts the hat back on so that RUTH coming downstairs doesn’t see his hair. He smiles at her, then at TERRI.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in an undertone) They want us off the streets. TERRI watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI sits on the sofa, with an Exchange and Mart open at the ‘Records’ page, a couple of ads circled. RUTH lies across his lap. TERRI sets down paper.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: You are everything to me. RUTH laughs, taken aback by the suddenness of it all.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I'll settle for being the most important. MARILYN comes into the room carrying a box.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Don’t mind me working here.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (into RUTH’s hair) Everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI walks away from Sorting Office opening a package: records. He walks on past boarded-up shops. A car appears on the far side of the street, traveling in the opposite direction.  19 20 14. TERRI pulls his chin down into his collar as it passes hi The sound of the car fades into the distance, leaving onl TERRI’s footsteps. Another car appears, moving slower, faces at the windows. TERRI retreats further into his collar. When the car has travelled a few yards beyond him it does a U-turn and before TERRI has time to run pulls up at the kerbside. A THUG jumps out. He pulls TERRI’s coat over his head and drags him towards the car. TERRI resists. At one stage his head is inside the car. He and the drive redheaded NED, are eye to eye.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Ned?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (lifting a wheel brace) Here, hit him a whack with this. TERRI in his panic flails, catching NED’s cheek with the record bag. He manages to break free, leaving his coat, sweater, and shirt in the hands of the THUG. Somehow he’s managed to hold on to the bag. He runs. THUG gets out and starts to give chase. Headlights appear further up the street.

dialogues.speaker: NED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Quick, get in. (holding a hand to his face) You’re a dead man, Hooley!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI, topless, stands back pressed against the wall, breathing heavily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI, RUTH’s dressing gown over his bare torso, is throwing brandy into him, pacing the floor. Terror has given way to anger. RUTH is trying to get him to sit down

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, you say you knew this fella?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: From the Sixties. He was a prick then and he’s a prick now, only now he’s a prick with a gun.  21 22 23 15. He sits finally, lights a cigarette and closes his eyes. RUTH sits on the arm of the chair beside him. Her gaze roams over his face.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Do you think maybe it’s time we got out of here?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: No, that’s what they expect - that’s what they want. He jumps up, knocking over the bag of records. They spill across the floor. He and RUTH start to pick them up. TERRI stops, straightens. RUTH looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Terri?

dialogues.speaker: BANK MANAGER
dialogues.text: Say that again.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I want to open a record shop.

dialogues.speaker: BANK MANAGER
dialogues.text: On Great Victoria Street? TERRI nods. BANK MANAGER (CONT’D) ‘Bomb Alley’?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A down-at-heel three-storey building in a late-Victorian terrace. TERRI and RUTH, DAVE and MARILYN look up at the frontage.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You’1l have to use a bit of imagination. They go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a wreck. There’s a dead pigeon on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (climbing the stairs) So, whole-food shop down here. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People’s printing press on the top floor. They have arrived on the first floor landing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you here in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: BANK MANAGER
dialogues.text: Do you know how long it’s been since I’ve had someone in here telling me he wanted to open something. He thinks. BANK MANAGER (CONT’D) I don’t suppose you have any collateral?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Collateral?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI, DAVE and RUTH walking at (TERRI’s) speed.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t get my hopes up.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: They got the Nobel Prize, Dave. A million pounds to promote peace and love! I and I is bringing reggae to the people of Belfast. They have stopped before a sign: PEACE PEOPLE.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Good luck. TERRI hugs her; hugs Dave too.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: One love. TERRI and DAVE go in. RUTH watches the door. Nothing happens; nothing happens; nothing happens. Then TERRI com out, DAVE follows.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fucking hippies.  26 27 17.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I don’t think the John Lennon story helped. TERRI and DAVE walk off. RUTH stands looking after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI and RUTH face one another across the table. He is brooding. She reaches under the table for her bag. She takes out an ID card.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I got a job. TERRI picks the card up and reads it.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Truant officer?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Don’t say anything. She takes money from her purse and counts it out on the table: ten, twenty, thirty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing that has changed is the BANK MANAGER’s tie TERRI is counting out the banknotes RUTH counted out for him: ten, twenty, thirty, and one note more.

dialogues.speaker: BANK MANAGER
dialogues.text: (picks up the notes) Forty pounds? He is tempted. He is also a bank manager. A moment. BANK MANAGER (CONT’D) You haven't anything a bit more... substantial? TERRI hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: You mean like a house? BANK MANAGER’s face brightens.  28 29 30 18.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (draws on his cigarette) No, it was all pretty straightforward. The forty quid swung it. (runs a finger round the phone’s change drawer) But, here, I might be home a bit late, I just have to go and do something about the, ah, sewers. TERRI pulls scraps of paper from his pocket; dials the number written on one particularly dog-eared scrap. A pause. A deep drag.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Marty? Terri Hooley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI walks up to a stall on which, among the other crap, are two big boxes of records ‘Pick of the Pops’ to the fo of one. He signals to STALL-HOLDER

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I‘ll give you a fiver for the whole lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI enters, the very incarnation of Johnny Guitar Watson’s ‘Gangster of Love’, a box under each arm. MARTY is there with a group of REPUBLICAN PARAMILITARIES (the FRIENDS from the 1968 Harp Bar), among them NED, bruising still around his eye. They watch TERRI stop before their table. He looks over h shoulder. ANDY enters with other LOYALIST PARAMILITARIES (more of the FRIENDS). The REPUBLICAN PARAMILITARIES instinctively rise from their seats hands going towards their jackets.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Why doesn’t everybody sit down? Both groups do, a wary distance apart. TERRI occupies the space between them.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know the old saying about the devil and the long spoon?  31 32 19. Everyone is looking at him, wondering where this is going

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought for a bunch of cunts like you a few LPs would probably do the trick. He fashions a smile, empties a box on one table, a box on the other and spreads the records out: jumble sale crap.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t all dive at once. A moment. They all dive at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tables are closer together. REPUBLICAN PARAMILITARIES and LOYALIST PARAMILITARIES are looking at their albums.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Wait, I already have Desperado. TERRI takes it back, gives him Leo Sayer’s Endless Flight passes Desperado to the Loyalist side.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Right, everybody happy? Nods, murmurs: they’re happy.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: OK, now, can I ask you something in return? See when this shop opens, there’s to be no coming round looking a “donation” for the Republican Prisoners... (looks left) «+. or the Loyal Orange Widows... (looks right) And one other thing, there’s to be no trying to kill me. Anybody. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now what about one for the road?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI stands at the door, smoking. ANDY comes to stand beside him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: That was some performance you put on there.  33 20.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I try my best.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: See those ones in there, though? They’re not the ones you have to worry about. Even the crazies remember the times before this all started. It’s the ones coming up behind them you’re going to have to watch out for. He nods across the street to where a couple of young skinheads wait: MUTT and HATCHET (who has a distinctive spiderweb tattoo on his neck).

dialogues.speaker: ANDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’ll take more than a few LPs to buy them off.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: You underestimate my record collection. ANDY pats TERRI’s cheek, without affection. He crosses th street. MUTT and HATCHET fall in behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A life-sized hardboard Elvis comes out the door. TERRI is behind, carrying it. He sets it on the footpath. The word Good Vibrations are painted in red below Elvis’s knees. H left index finger points the way back up the stairs. There is a lame pop. Cheers. The BOD from the Wholefood shop dispenses Elderflower Champagne to DAVE, MARILYN, RUTH, and TERRI. (TERRI slips flask from his pocket and tops up his own ‘champagne’ wit brandy.) A little sea of celebration in the middle of Bom Alley’s wrecked shop fronts and steel shutters A guy with wild hair and greying beard comes down the street: PUGWASH. He stops and looks.

dialogues.speaker: PUGWASH
dialogues.text: You actually open?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Yeah, we’re open. PUGWASH raises his arms as though to be searched. TERRI hugs him.  34 35 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night is falling. The street is deserted, the buildings i darkness. There is only one figure in the street: Elvis. There is only one light on: Good Vibrations’s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand (TERRI’s) flicks a light switch; presses a button open a cash register; pours coins into the drawers; flips open a receipt book. Finally the hand removes a record fr a sleeve: the Wailers’ Catch a Fire. Sets it on the turntable; lowers the needle. The music swells; TERRI is at the counter, the Outlaws gallery from the Harp on the wall behind him; he looks up There are all of two customers, PUGWASH and A.N.OTHER A.N.OTHER lifts an album.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (shouts ) Great choice, Too Many Saviours on my Cross! A.N.OTHER sets it down and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: PUGWASH
dialogues.text: It'd be wasted on him.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: You're probably right. TWO RUC MEN enter.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST RUC MAN
dialogues.text: See business is going well.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Early days.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST RUC MAN
dialogues.text: (picks up Wailers sleeve: Marley toking) Your old chum Eric has left a bit of a gap in the market and we have our suspicions about who's filled it.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you talking about? It’s a record shop!  36 37 38 22.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST RUC MAN
dialogues.text: So you say. But see if we so much as find two cigarette papers in the same room, it’1ll be an ex- record shop. He sets down the sleeve on his way out. SECOND RUC MAN follows; FIRST RUC MAN turns at the door. FIRST RUC MAN (CONT’D) By the way, is your man out the front anything to do with you? TERRI walks to the window getting there just as the track ends. GEORGE is out on Great Victoria Street, pointing th same way as Elvis.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don’t let the name fool you. Good Vibrations? Naked capitalism is what it is!

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Fuck sake, dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s the end of the day. Elvis is entering the building, TERRI, as previously, behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI counts the takings. He lifts the cash drawer to see if he’s missed any. He hasn't. He looks around the empty shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI locks up. He lights a cigarette. He hears youthful laughter. His head turns, looks up an alley, at the same moment as RUTH appears behind him

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Boo. TERRI drops the cigarette down his jumper.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought I’d walk you home. TERRI has one hand down his jumper the other hand up. The up hand retrieves the cigarette, the down hand beats his chest.  23. A TV CREW has set up on the footpath. An earnest journali - DES - delivers a piece to camera.

dialogues.speaker: DES
dialogues.text: For the people of Belfast the nightmare continues. TERRI and RUTH walk through his shot without interrupting their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: How was it today?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Another few customers wouldn’t hurt. One or two under thirty wouldn’t hurt either. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I haven’t spoken to anyone over the age of twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day in the shop. TERRI looks glum. PUGWASH steps up to the counter with a Shangri-las album.

dialogues.speaker: PUGWASH
dialogues.text: Just the one today, Terri.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Ah, Pugwash, beehives and teenage suicide... we obviously share the same taste in women. Three pound. PUGWASH goes. Behind him stands an odd-looking urchin. Th is FANGS, a Belfast punk, missing a few front teeth.

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: Have you ‘Orgasm Addict’?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I think you’re in the wrong shop.

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: Buzzcocks?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Definitely in the wrong shop.

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: Fuck Off?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: What?  24.

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: If you don’t want to fuck me fuck off, the Electric Chairs? TERRI shakes his head. FANGS looks around.

dialogues.speaker: FANGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought this was supposed to be a record shop. They stare at one another. TERRI recognises something in the kid’s attitude. He gets a pen, a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I’1l order them. DAVE enters carrying posters, which he gives to FANGS

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Here you go, hot off the press. FANGS instantly hands one to TERRI.

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: (not asking, telling) Stick that up for us. TERRI unrolls it: JANUARY 12TH - RUDI AND THE OUTCASTS - THE POUND, TOWNHALL STREET.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: A gig? Who’s putting that on?

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: Us. TERRI looks at the poster again. When he looks up FANGS i already heading for the door.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Here, where are you hearing all that stuff you were asking me for?

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: Peel.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: John Peel? Last time I heard he was playing Pink Floyd. He turns to the wall, looking for a space. When he can’t see one he takes down the Rolling Stones Ulster Hall bill

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry, boys.  40 4l 42 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI and DAVE and their echoing footsteps are walking aw from the city centre. Sound of an army helicopter overhea

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: If I’d known you were going to drag me down here I’d never have printed that thing. He glances anxiously over his shoulder then has to quick- step to catch up with TERRI

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know they used the Pound as a morgue on Bloody Friday.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Fuck sake, Dave. They pass in front of the Albert Clock, round a corner, round another, and there is the Pound, a once-fine bar no barely standing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: There'll be nobody here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are people all right. Young people. PUNKS. It’s another city, another world entirely. The journey from the door to the bar is a crash course in teen vice, 1978 vintage: gropings, playful headbuttings, surreptitious glue-sniffing. TERRI and DAVE squeeze in at the bar. DAVE takes out a pound note, conspicuous amid the PUNKS counting out their coins so of course the BARMAN makes straight for him. The PUNKS glare. TERRI turns to look into the room. On a stage lit by a single fluorescent bulb, four crop- haired teenagers are wrenching out a song (basic even for punk) from their instruments. These are the OUTCASTS. Lead singer GREG COWAN exercises his snarl. Guitarist GETTY, shirt off, concentrates so hard on his guitar, he doesn’t notice the girls concentrating on him. Suddenly a number of RUC MEN come in and start nabbing anyone who looks underage (and plenty do), taking names, asking for pockets to be turned out.  26. TERRI pushes his way through the crowd and buttonholes an RUC MAN, writing down the name of a pink-haired PUNK GIRL

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Excuse me, officer, I’d like to report a civil war outside. RUC MAN turns. It’s the man who warned TERRI in the shop.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not you again.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST RUC MAN
dialogues.text: Step back, Hooley.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: No, really, take your time. The bombing, shooting, intimidation, that can all wait while you smell her breath to see if she’s been drinking.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST RUC MAN
dialogues.text: (to PUNK GIRL) Stay you there. (to TERRI) And, you, I’ve warned you once: step back. TERRI steps forward. FIRST RUC MAN’s hand moves towards t gun at his hip. Suddenly a single guitar chord sounds. Another band has taken the stage. What they lack in snarl they make up for in cheek. This is RUDI. Down on the floor TERRI and RUC MAN are still squaring up RUDI’s singer RONNIE MATTHEWS leans into the mike.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: (more spoken than sung) We hate the cops. TERRI and RUC MAN finally look at the stage where RUDI ar ripping into ‘Cops’. The audience have forgotten about th actual RUC MEN among them and are singing along.

dialogues.speaker: PUNKS
dialogues.text: We hate the cops, we hate the cops. TERRI joins in, right in NEAREST COP’s face. The atmosphe has changed, the RUC have lost control. By the door of the bar an RUC SERGEANT gives the signal t withdraw. RUC MAN reluctantly backs off TERRI who is givi it all he has got.  43 27.

dialogues.speaker: SS RUC, SS RUC.
dialogues.text: When the last cop has gone there is pandemonium. TERRI is in the thick of it, hugging PUNKS, getting head-butted (accidentally? Maybe not, though he appears not to mind).

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: OK, now that we’ve cleared the air a bit... this is ‘Big Time’. At guitarist BRIAN YOUNG’s opening riff the crowd surges forward. Suddenly the fluorescent stage-light falls from the ceiling. RUDI play on regardless in the gloom. FANGS grabs the light, still lit, and swings it above his head. TERRI looks around him - at the kids, at the band, at the waving light - and it is all too much. He starts to cry. Then he jumps up and down with everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI leans at the bar his head in his hands. DAVE approaches.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (raises his head) All right? I’ve lost a tooth, been drenched in spit, called a wanker about five hundred times. (with a nod to barman) And I hate to tell you, but this beer tastes like piss... It’s the best night I’ve had in Belfast in years. He turns. His eye is missing. DAVE hands him the pint gla at his elbow. There is the eye, floating in the beer. TERRI plunges his hand in, shakes the eye dry and pops it back in just as BRIAN and RONNIE of RUDI approach. TERRI pushes DAVE aside.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Boys, where have you been all my life? He hugs each one in turn, unaware quite how little the bo want to be hugged.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Do we know you?  28.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Terri Hooley. I run a record shop and that ‘Big Time’ song... (he sings the riff) I want that in my shop.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: You can want all you like.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Are you telling me you haven’t recorded it?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Recorded it? Who’s going to come to Belfast to sign us.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: That’s just the way it is. We don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Fuck sake, raise your expectations. (a pause) I‘1l do it. I’11 put it out.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: You're pissed.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: So what? DAVE arrives at TERRI’s shoulder just in time to hear...

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’1ll put that record out.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I don’t know. (to DAVE) How hard can it be? RUDI look at one another and laugh.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Whatever you think, mate.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I'll be in touch during the week. You're making a record, fellas. TERRI and DAVE head for the exit.  44 29.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You just can’t go charging into something like that... Anyway, we're meant to be a collective.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: We are, you can print the sleeves. Two OUTCASTS approach, singer GREG, a bottle of cider in his hand, and GETTY, Pink-haired PUNK GIRL hanging on to his... until her BOYFRIEND grabs her back.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Here, will you record us too?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I’m not that fucking pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bedroom door opens with a bang. TERRI framed by the hall light.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: You’1l never believe what I’ve just seen. RUTH sits up in bed, struggling to open her eyes. TERRI pulls back the covers, gets into bed.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These kids... they don’t give a shit. You have to hear them.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Now? What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Four. You have to hear them.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Right, right.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Everybody has to hear them.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Right. (pause) Have you still your shoes on? A thump as one shoe lands on the floor. Another thump.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Everybody.  45 46 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH is asleep. Terri is awake staring at the ceiling. Th ceiling is a movie screen; TERRI, in Hank Williams’s famo white suit, with rhinestone music notes, is on stage at t Pound with RUDI, the OUTCASTS and a host of PUNKS singing ‘I Saw the Light’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIAN and TERRI enter. Two men are in conversation at a mixing desk, one - in a multi-coloured suede patchwork co - standing (DAVY SMYTH) the other - lank hair, cheeseclot shirt - sitting (DAVY SHANNON)

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Which of you is Davy? Both men look up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVY SMYTH
dialogues.text: We both are.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (under his breath) That’s all I need, another two Davys in my life. (aloud) I phoned earlier... Terri Hooley? BRIAN is looking around in wonder. The DAVYS are looking BRIAN like he’s another life form.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So when can you fit us in? DAVY SMYTH opens a desk diary.

dialogues.speaker: DAVY SMYTH
dialogues.text: I don’t know, we’re pretty full.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: You're joking me?

dialogues.speaker: DAVY SMYTH
dialogues.text: We've a couple of flute bands in next week, and we've a jingle for cheese and onion crisps. BRIAN has gone for a wander: a kid in a toy shop. TERRI sidles up and drapes an arm over DAVY SMYTH’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Come on, is that what you had in mind when you set this place up? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Flute bands and crisp commercials?

dialogues.speaker: DAVY SMYTH
dialogues.text: The times we live in. You have to put the dinner on the table somehow. TERRI takes out a spliff, which he lights it, letting the smoke out slowly.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: And what about your rock’n’‘roll soul, Davy... Davys. How do you feed those? DAVY SMYTH looks again at BRIAN then at DAVY SHANNON and finally at the diary.

dialogues.speaker: DAVY SMYTH
dialogues.text: I can give you an hour the Tuesday after next. 10 OK?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: In the morning? Come on, we're music people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANK MANAGER holds a 45: Zoot Sims ‘Dream’.

dialogues.speaker: BANK MANAGER
dialogues.text: (a touch of awe) This brings back memories.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Amazing isn’t it. A bit of cardboard and some pressed plastic. BANK MANAGER goes to hand it back. TERRI waves it away.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All that magic - 14p.

dialogues.speaker: BANK MANAGER
dialogues.text: 14p to buy?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: 14p to make yourself. That’s recording...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI stands behind DAVY SMYTH at the desk, watching RUDI  49 50 51 52 DAVY points at the clock. Three minutes past the hour. TERRI slips him another twenty quid.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Pressing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vinyl being pressed.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The sleeves are taken care of.
49 50 A3 sheets fall from DAVE’s printing press. TERRI, RUTH, MARILYN and DAVE lift them as quickly as they come out an fold them.

dialogues.speaker: BANK MANAGER
dialogues.text: 14p. So how many were you thinking of doing?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Three thousand. BANK MANAGER’s eyebrows go up.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 51 52 DAVE, BRIAN and RONNIE watch TERRI remove a piece of viny from a ‘Big Time’ sleeve and holds it up, like the host.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Up your hole, EMI.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I thought you were sending it to EMI and Polydor?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I know but up their hole anyway. We cracked the code, we made it without them. BRIAN and RONNIE make a grab for the pile of records on t counter, turning them over in their hands.  53 54 33. EXT. HARP BAR —- AFTERNOON 53 TERRI and RUTH enter. RUTH carries a packet of biscuits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few OLD WANKERS dotted around watching a stripper on a stage. XXX film projected on the wall behind her. TERRI, RUTH, and PAT walk in from the back.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: What - them squirrely-looking bastards you see glue-sniffing in Corn Market? (lowering his voice) And doesn’t ‘punk’ mean ‘fruit’? I wouldn’t want any of that sort of carry-on. He leans forward to pick up an empty glass and some of th XXX carry-on is briefly projected on to his face.

dialogues.speaker: PAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought they all hung out in the Pound anyway.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: One night a week. They need a place of their own. RUTH stares straight ahead at the STRIPPER TERRI approaches the stage; bends down for a closer look it. Above him the stripper carries on, oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Better stage than the Pound and all. Turns to RUTH.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Those are amazing shoes. STRIPPER smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (to PAT) How many does this place hold on a good night?  55 56 34.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: A good night? I can’t remember the last time we had one of them.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I can. It holds three hundred. Some of these kids are only wee. I'd say three-fifty once the word spreads. PAT’s swaying.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Three or four nights a week. PAT’s swayed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAVIS opens the door. TERRI and RUTH on doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Sorry we're a wee bit late. We were...

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Bomb scare. She hands MAVIS the biscuits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI, RUTH, MAVIS and GEORGE are having dinner. Throughout, MAVIS attempts to keep up a hostess’s (and mother-in-law’s) politeness. A VOTE HOOLEY poster is clearly visible in the background

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Pass me the salt there.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: The potatoes are lovely.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: They’re George’s own. You should get him to take you round the garden after dinner. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t think it, all the size of it, but he could feed half the street out of it. And many’s the time he has. Haven't you, George? GEORGE grunts in reply. He has been biding his time.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (to TERRI) So you’re a shop owner and a record company boss now too, are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (to RUTH) And how’s your job going?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: It would break your heart, some of those estates. There’s kids in their teens have already given up. They think the only way to get themselves noticed is to wrap themselves in a flag and pick up a gun.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (to TERRI) This is the same lad used to march around town with me shouting... CHILD TERRI appears on GEORGE’s shoulders, a big eye patc an even bigger placard.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD TERRI AND GEORGE TOGETHER
dialogues.text: Property is theft! Property is theft!

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Catch yourself on, dad. CHILD TERRI disappears.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not like you think. All I’ve promised these bands is to get them heard. I’ve sent the record out to every record company in London.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (to TERRI) And?  36.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I’m still waiting on them getting back to me.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Of course you are. It’s the most rotten industry there is: bribes, payola, cartels. Get involved in that you’ll either end up a crook or you’ll go broke.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I’ll never be a crook.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (to RUTH) It’s the parents need the talking to, not the kids. Kids will only do what they’re let get away with.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (to GEORGE) Actually, I’m taking a couple of the groups out on the road next month.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, MAVIS, RUTH
dialogues.text: (as one) What?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Just a few dates, just to let people see what’s going on here.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Are you sure it’s wise, driving around this country in a van at night? Those poor fellas who were murdered... GEORGE buts in.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Aw, don’t talk to him. He’s an impresario. The Lew Grade of Great Victoria Street. TERRI’s had enough.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: How many elections is it you’ve lost? Ten. Did it ever occur to you there might be more than one alternative? GEORGE is about to come back, but MAVIS has had enough to She thrusts a gravy boat between them.  37.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: More gravy anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH and TERRI wave to GEORGE and MAVIS.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (through a fixed smile) I’d have to speak to them at work about taking time off if you want me to cover at the shop.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: It’s OK, I’1ll get Pugwash to do it.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Pugwash? Can you afford him?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I’m not going to pay him. He practically lives there anyway. Fucker’s lucky I don’t charge him rent. TERRI walks on. RUTH stares after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREG and GETTY load equipment into a dilapidated white va Rudi’s BRIAN arrives carrying a guitar case, as GETTY staggers out of the shop with an amp.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Are these the Rudi roadies? GREG passes, carrying a box.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Ha fucking ha.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (to BRIAN) Meet your new label-mates.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: You’ve changed your tune.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Well, I’d have grown old waiting on them changing theirs. GETTY walks back towards the shop, rubbing his sides, feigning laughter.  38.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Anyone else coming on this tour?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Tearjerkers... FANGS and LANKY PUNK stroll up.

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: Can we come?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: -.. these two... BRIAN puts his guitar case in the minibus.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Uncle Terri, come on! Laughter. TERRI goes to get into the van. Stops.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Wait, does anybody know how to drive this thing?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: We’re your fucking stars, you can’t ask us to drive. GETTY coming from the shop takes the keys out of TERRI’s hand without a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheep, cows, army watchtowers. The van, amps and faces tight against the windows, passes across the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GETTY drives. TERRI, by the passenger window, drinks.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Where the fuck are we?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (a swig from the bottle) We’re on the road to Damascus.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: That last sign said Loughbrickland.  61 62 63 64 65 66 67 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van carries on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIAN at the mike.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Hello, Damascus, we’re RUDI. RUDI play ‘I-Spy’. The rest of the GOOD VIBES CREW huddle in front of the stage. The dance-floor is otherwise empty The walls are lined with LOCAL LADS looking daggers and LOCAL GIRLS looking torn. TERRI, watching from beside the band, beckons to someone down the hall. A RURAL PUNK kid comes forward, baited by the LOCAL LADS; when he reaches the front he closes his eyes and pogos like his life depends on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More cows, more sheep, more watchtowers. Posters appear: Good Vibes on Tour at Stranocum... Pettigo... Garrison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUDI still play, RURAL PUNK has been joined by a couple more of the LOCAL LADS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More posters advertising more venues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dance floor is fuller, pogoing, beer glasses flying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The floor is a mess: broken glass, tables overturned. TERRI has his hand out to the RURAL HALL MANAGER. The RUR HALL MANAGER jerks a thumb over his shoulder at the mayhe TERRI’s bands are leaving in their wake. He puts his hand out to TERRI. TERRI reaches for his wallet...  68 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van is parked, doors open. The GOOD VIBES CREW are lined up, pissing into a ditch. Only TERRI and GETTY rema in the bus. TERRI is looking for a light. He empties his jacket pockets on to the dashboard: half a dozen cassette

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: People keep handing me these fucking things. RONNIE pissing nearest the bus pipes up.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: They wouldn’t be doing it if they knew what happened to ‘Big Time’.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Or what didn’t happen.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Hasn't happened yet. I’m still waiting on calls from London. Maybe when we get back... TERRI pulls out another tape.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t even remember where the half of them came from. There is a rustle in the bushes, then lights, shouts.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER 1
dialogues.text: Everybody down on the fucking ground! Out! Out! Out! He trails TERRI out of minibus. SOLDIERS everywhere, faces blackened, guns poised. TERRI forced to the ground beside GETTY who has been dragged round from the other side.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Whoa! Whoa!

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER 1
dialogues.text: I said fucking down. SOLDIERS are frisking the prone punks. They drag them all up on their feet again.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER 1, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the fuck have we here? Fucking scarecrow convention?  4l.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Listen, fellas, we’ve been playing some dates. We’re on our way home to Belfast.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER 1
dialogues.text: And where are you all from in Belfast?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN/GREG/FANGS/LANKY PUNK
dialogues.text: East - West - South - North. They look down the line at one another as it registers.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER 1
dialogues.text: (in BRIAN’s face) Are you taking the mick, Mick? BRIAN’s face says that he wouldn’t dream of it.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER 1, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (turns to TERRI) You telling me some of these cunts are Protestant and some of them are Catholic?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: It never occurred to me to ask.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER 1
dialogues.text: You ever think of setting up a political party?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: You don’t want to know what I think of political parties.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER 1
dialogues.text: You don’t want to know what we do either. (calls to his patrol) All right, let them back on to their bus. The GOOD VIBES CREW climb on board, cocky again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound of the soldiers’ radio as the engine starts.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER 1
dialogues.text: (taps TERRI’s window) Just getting reports in on the radio. You might want to watch yourselves going West when you get to Belfast... And North. A bit of trouble in the East too.  70 71 72 73 42.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: What about the South?

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER 1
dialogues.text: You should be OK if you get going now. The van pulls off: bare arses pressed against the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van drives through the streets of Belfast. The mood h changed. Nervous glances. An ambulance passes, siren wailing. There are flames on the skyline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI wakes as RUTH gets out of bed. The clothes we saw h in in the last scene are strewn around the room.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Any calls while I was away?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Nothing. TERRI throws himself back on the bed. He looks up at the ceiling. HANK WILLIAMS shakes his head sadly. TERRI squeezes his eyes shut.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Don’t fucking start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH stands in the living room doorway taking in the scen Various OUTCASTS and TEARJERKERS are asleep on the floor. RUTH steps over them on her way to the kitchen. GETTY is the only one to wake.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Getty.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: All right, Ruth? Sorry about this. There was a bit of trouble last night. He wouldn’t let us go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH puts kettle on, takes down a jar of instant coffee. GETTY comes in. Lights a cigarette. She gets an extra cup from the cupboard.  74 75 76 77 43.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: How was the countryside.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Weird. RUTH waits for more. There isn’t any. They sip their coffee. She sets her cup down.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Well, I’1l see you later.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH picks her way with care again. Near the door she ben down and shakes FANGS awake.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Should you not be at school?

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: (burrowing down again) Saint’s Day. RUTH gives up. She opens the door. ‘This Perfect Day’ by the Saints plays, as it does throug the next few scenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH sits by the window, reading EMILY DICKINSON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI opens the shop door bends to pick up the post. All bills. TERRI walks behind the counter and opens a drawer, which is already full of bills. He closes it quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every lamppost has an Ulster flag. THREE ESTATE KIDS - lo hair - sit on a wall before a large mural ‘Join the Ulste Young Militants’. RUTH approaches. They start to run. RUTH runs after them, then stops, throws her hands in the air in frustration. She lifts the windscreen wiper of a nearby car, puts a flyer beneath it: ‘Harp Bar, Punk Club’  78 79 80

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LANKY PUNK running. A few seconds behind and gaining are MUTT and HATCHET. LANKY PUNK ducks in the doorway of No. 102. MUTT and HATCHET follow and find themselves face to face with TERR

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (arm across the doorway) You're barred.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: You can’t bar us, we’ve never even been in before.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Well, for giving me lip you're definitely barred now.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: (in TERRI’s face) I know people. I could have you shot.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I know the same people you know. I could have you sent to bed without your supper. MUTT glares a moment longer then knocks TERRI’s arm out o the way. Good Vibes CUSTOMERS are massed on the stairs. FANGS, PUGWASH... Even a few of the WHOLEFOOD BODS. MUTT contemplates the odds, thinks better of it, though he can resist a parting shot.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: See from now on? You better make sure you have someone with you every time you turn your back to piss, because I’m the fucking bogeyman and I swear to fuck, sooner or later, I’m going to get you. He turns and floors ELVIS with a single punch. HATCHET lingers for a sneer. ELVIS, rebounding, nearly smacks him in the face as he turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheering from Good Vibes CUSTOMERS as TERRI walks through

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TEARJERKERS do a cover of the Saints track just heard  81 82 83 45. RUDI and the OUTCASTS are in the crowd, attracting as muc attention as the band on stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI at the door watches the PUNKS still queueing up to get in. RUTH appears behind him, wraps her arms around hi

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: You know what this place is starting to remind me of?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Itself. A long-haired KID passes clutching a flyer. He nods at RUTH, who recognises him from the estate; nods back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH and TERRI fucking with abandon. This perfect day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shop is practically empty - PUGWASH, a couple of PUNK DAVE. TERRI drops Alka Seltzer into a glass. He has a letter in his other hand, an open package on the counter front of him a returned Big Time 7” sticking out of it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Dear Mr Hooley go fuck yourself... again. (he scrunches it up) I thought making the record was supposed to be the hard bit.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: It’s Belfast...

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: No, it’s London. Might as well be the moon.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Maybe we should just stick to what we know we can do in future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As DAVE leaves, five teens in sports jackets and parkas enter: the UNDERTONES. They are in no mood for idle chitc

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Something you're looking for?

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL
dialogues.text: Aye, you. Billy here sent you a tape ages ago...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (interjecting) The Undertones...

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL
dialogues.text: We haven't heard a thing.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I have a shop to run. I’m a busy man.

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL
dialogues.text: Have you even listened to it yet? TERRI hesitates a second.

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Great. We trek all the way down from Derry and you haven’t even listened to it.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I didn’t say that. Jesus, you Derry ones.

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY
dialogues.text: So, did you like it?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: It wasn’t bad.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Wasn't bad...?

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL
dialogues.text: There’s no way you listened to it then. Every song on that tape is a hit.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: It’s too early in the morning for this shit. He pats his pockets.  47.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are my fags? He can’t find any.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck sake. Anyone got any fags? CUSTOMERS look up and shake their heads.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Call yourself punks. (to UNDERTONES ) You any fags?

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL
dialogues.text: Smoked them all on the bus. TERRI comes out from behind the counter, shaking his head

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Steer the ship while I’m away, Pugwash. TERRI leaves. BILLY nods to FEARGAL: go after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI strides along; FEARGAL keeps up the pace, and chat.

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL
dialogues.text: I still think you’re bluffing.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: The thing is - what did you say your name was?

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL
dialogues.text: Feargal. Feargal Sharkey.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Feargal. The thing is, Good Vibrations isn’t really a proper label...

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL
dialogues.text: If we don’t get a record out soon it’ll be too late. We’re breaking up. TERRI stops dead. He looks physically pained.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Aw, now don’t lay that on me. Listen, all I wanted was to open a record shop.  85 48.

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL
dialogues.text: But you put out Rudi.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I know but that was because...

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL
dialogues.text: And the Outcasts. There’s no answer to that. They are at a pedestrian crossing facing a newsagent’s.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Tell you what. I’m going over there to buy some fags. When I get back I'll give you an answer.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: TERRI crosses over and goes into the shop. He emerges a f moments later, unwraps the packet, takes out a cigarette, lights it. FEARGAL on the other side of the street taps his wrist. TERRI can’t help himself: he smiles, though does his best to hide it with his cigarette. He crosses the road again.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I must need my head examined. He walks on, leaving FEARGAL smirking in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The UNDERTONES sing the opening lines of ‘True Confession a band transformed. DAVY SHANNON is hunched over the mixing desk in the contr room. TERRI comes in. He unloads beer, crisps, rolls, fro carrier bags. FEARGAL stops abruptly, takes off the headphones. DAVY SHANNON fades up his voice.

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL
dialogues.text: All I’m getting is echo, echo, echo. DAVE SHANNON adjusts level.

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY
dialogues.text: OK, try it from the top again.  86 87 88
DAVY SHANNON shuts down the studio link. BILLY silently counts the band in and FEARGAL starts to sing again.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Hard going?

dialogues.speaker: DAVY SMYTH
dialogues.text: Never been in a proper studio two hours ago, now they’re the producers. In the studio the band have stopped again.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: What do you think, will we just cut our losses here?

dialogues.speaker: DAVY SHANNON
dialogues.text: (suddenly animated) Cut our losses? You didn’t hear them do the track before this. That was the best thing I ever recorded. The best thing anyone in this city ever recorded. He hands TERRI headphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band’s side of the glass between the control room and studio proper. TERRI clutches the headphones to his ears. He walks slowl to the glass. He spreads his hands against it.

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL
dialogues.text: (waving, through gritted teeth) Stop staring at me like that, you mad one-eyed bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI takes off the headphones as though afraid of lettin the track he’s just heard escape.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Well I won’t be posting this one to London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI holds up the A3 ‘Teenage Kicks’ sleeve to an audien of UNDERTONES, OUCASTS, RUDI, DAVE, MARILYN, RUTH, FANGS, PUGWASH.  89 50.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Thank you all for answering the call. Now, are you watching? You line up the record with the top edge, fold along the bottom line, like this, then fold down this side and then this... (holds it up) And there you have it. Again? (repeats routine only faster) Here, here, here, and here. Right, now, let’s get started. The mass folding of ‘Teenage Kicks’ EP sleeves begins. There is beer, there is larking about. Then the door open and there is GEORGE. TERRI scrambles to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I heard what was going on here tonight. TERRI looks pleased.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Exploiting these kids. (hands TERRI a cassette) Play that for them. Loud. TERRI turns his back to put it on, loud as instructed. It ‘The Internationale’: ‘Stand up you victims of oppression for the tyrants fear your might’ etc. GEORGE meanwhile is taking in the scene, the camaraderie. For a moment it looks as though he might be about to smil TERRI turns back, catches his eye. GEORGE sets his jaw again, reverting to type. TERRI goes back to turntable, turns the record even louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only TERRI, RUTH and PUGWASH remain. Piles of Teenage Kic all around. TERRI is trying to squeeze just one more copy into a plastic bag...

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I think you’ve maybe enough in there.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (forcing it) Just in case...  90 91 51.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Calm. You’1ll be grand.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I’m glad you think so.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: They’1l never have met anyone like you. I know I hadn’t. Still haven't.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I don’t want to give them any excuse.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You won't. (kisses him) I’ve got to get on to work. She turns to leave, but stops in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just promise me you won’t tell the John Lennon story.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (hand on his heart) Swear to Bob Marley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI knocks at a glossily painted townhouse door. Which opened, at length, by ERIC, still the Sixth Stone, only n more Miss You than Main Street. He grins. INT. ERIC’S PAD - DAY 91 A huge, white, mirrored palace.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Holy fuck.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I know. Amazing where charm, know- how and labyrinthine narcotics connections can get a young man these days... TERRI has stopped to look at the signed photos on the wal Sly Stone, Keith Moon, the James Last Orchestra.  92 93 52.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Have you had a lot of dealings with music people?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: That's like asking a vet if he’s stuck his hand up a cow’s arse. He has produced a bag of white powder.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Something to help you on your way?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Better not. I can’t afford to fuck up.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: You'll fuck up if you’re too tense. You have to go in there like you mean it.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Good point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terri is flying through London, record bag under his arm. Children wave. He waves back, throws them records. He passes some PEARLY KINGS AND QUEENS. They give him the thumbs up. Terri replies in kind. INT. FIRST RECORD EXEC’S OFFICE. DAY 93 An EXECUTIVE, swivels in his seat. He has a fashionable N Wave haircut, and an expression that suggests TERRI’s not the first person to fly through his window.

dialogues.speaker: NEW WAVE EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: Where are the guns? TERRI drops like a lead weight into a chair at the opposi side of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: NEW WAVE EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: The guns? The bombs? The tanks...

dialogues.speaker: NEW WAVE EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: The rage? I get told here’s a punk band from Belfast. I think, yeah, great, no pissing around here, this should be real darkness, proper darkness. He lifts a copy of the single. NEW WAVE EXECUTIVE (CONT’D) But then I get... this. Nihilism? If anything it sounds like they’re having too good a time. TERRI jumps to his feet, grabs his records and storms out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy looks like a schoolboy.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOLBOY EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: They're no oil-paintings are they? Have they any good looking friends? And we love it when bands sing in regional accents, but could they not pick another region? TERRI’S knuckles whiten as he grips his chair. He jumps up, the chair falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI sits facing a ROARING DICKHEAD.

dialogues.speaker: ROARING DICKHEAD EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: It’s shit.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Shit? TERRI’S head slumps forward. He looks beaten.

dialogues.speaker: ROARING DICKHEAD EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: Yeah, shit. TERRI looks up, scans the room: the photos, the gold disc

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (deep breath; stands) It’s not shit.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: It’s not.

dialogues.speaker: ROARING DICKHEAD EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: Is. TERRI lifts a disc from the wall. He looks demented.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: No, this is shit The EXECUTIVE slowly starts to back away from the table..

dialogues.speaker: ROARING DICKHEAD EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: (shouting) Cathy, get security up here now. ++.Just in time to duck as TERRI hurls the disc at him. He grabs another.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: And this is shit. He throws it. Then picks another.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And this is really shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOUR PUNKS stand with a soberly-dressed MANAGER, laughing as they wait for the lift. A ting. The lift doors open. The FOUR PUNKS step back in horror as TERRI is frog-marched out by two SECURITY MEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI is thrown on to the street. His bag of records follows behind. He gets up, lifts a bunch of Teenage Kicks, shakes them a the SECURITY MEN - at the whole building.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you people? He turns round, glares at the passers-by - tries with little success to hand them copies.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is there not one person in this city who recognises genius when it’s handed to them?  98 99 55. A thought hits him. He runs to the kerb and hails a cab.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BBC PORTLAND PLACE
dialogues.text: An Evening Standard pavement poster reads SCOTLAND YARD I IRA CELL HUNT. TERRI gets out of the cab and makes for the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BBC PORTLAND PLACE
dialogues.text: TERRI, hunched over the reception desk, tries to foist an envelope on the RECEPTIONIST who refuses even to touch it

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: It’s just that all packages have to be signed in. Security.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: It’s a piece of vinyl.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: New regulations.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Can you sign for it?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I’m afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I’ve come all the way from Belfast and to tell you the truth I've fucked up a bit today. RECEPTIONIST, alarmed by ‘Belfast’, glances towards SECURITY GUARDS over by the revolving door.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (to TERRI) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: No. TERRI drops to his knees on the far side of the desk. He moans. SECURITY GUARDS step forward, but before they get him a BBC employee, DES, comes through the door.

dialogues.speaker: DES
dialogues.text: Terri? The moaning stops.  100 56.

dialogues.speaker: DES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Terri Hooley? TERRI looks up, gets up, as though he had simply been retrieving something from his bag.

dialogues.speaker: DES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it. TERRI clearly hasn’t the first idea who DES is.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (to DES) Is this man a friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: DES
dialogues.text: I was doing a story in Belfast at New Year and wandered into his record shop. He had a 13th Floor Elevators album...

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Easter Everywhere, International Artists deleted it the year after it was released.

dialogues.speaker: DES
dialogues.text: I’d searched all over London for it. (to TERRI) What are you doing here? TERRI’s face brightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI’s face darkens. He and RUTH sit either side of the radio. JOHN PEEL is coming on air. TERRI stands up.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I can’t listen to this.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: It’s only been four nights.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: It’s my fault. I should have run up those stairs and handed it over myself. It would have been worth being arrested He switches off the radio, walks out of the room.  101 102 103 104 57.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (switching radio on again) Did it ever occur to you I might be listening to that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI on the toilet reading Emily Dickinson. A sound from downstairs. Again. RUTH is shouting his name

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Living room. RUTH is rooted to the spot. Her shouts drown the radio.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
