dialogues.text: Terri! Terri! TERRI bursts in as ‘Teenage Kicks’ ends.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You missed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand lifts the needle from the run-off groove.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PEEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Isn't that the best thing you’ve ever heard? It’s so good I’m going to do something I’ve never done before. The hand sets the needle on the start of the record again

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A teenage dream’s so hard to beat, every time she walks down the street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI and RUTH jump around the living room in celebration The phone rings. RUTH answers.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Hello, Dave. I know, I know, isn’t it amazing? Twice in a row! The doorbell rings. TERRI goes to the door. FANGS and two other PUNKS are on the doorstep. FANGS has a transistor round his wrist. He holds it up like a holy relic.  105 106 58.

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: John fucking Peel! TERRI stands aside, the PUNKS wander in. TERRI goes out o to the street. All the while the record plays

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI stands in the street, face tilted towards the sky. There’s an army helicopter up there. A spotlight roves backwards and forward. TERRI’s face is turns lit up and cast in shadow, lit up and cast in shado

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Get teenage kicks right through the night, all right.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (murmurs ) I still say it’s about wanking. Inside Number 12 the phone rings again... is answered. A few moments later RUTH appears and calls to TERRI.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Terri there’s a fella on the phone says he’s from Sire Records in London. TERRI continues to look skywards, his eyes slowly closing another prayer answered.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Terri? The fella’s hanging on here. He opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Tell him if he wants to talk to me he can come over here and do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In background a plane lands. The ‘fella from Sire’ PAUL McNALLY makes his way, across the tarmac. THREE SOLDIERS pass, PAUL MCNALLY flinches. TERRI leans on the dilapidated van from the Good Vibes tour, holding up a placard on which are written two words ‘The Man’.  59.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Terri Hooley by any chance? TERRI tosses away the ‘Man’ placard.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Paul McNally.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Have you any fags? I’m right out. He opens the passenger door. GETTY is in the driver's sea

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is Getty, he’s driving us to Derry. GETTY salutes. PAUL goes to get in the front.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold on, you’re in the back.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (about to get out) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Only kidding. I’m in the back. We'll swap at Bellaghy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van passes a sign ‘Bellaghy’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI is still in the back.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Seymour Stein was knocked out by ‘Kicks’.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: ‘Kicks’?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He turned to me straight away and said, ‘I want that band’. That’s the way he was with the Ramones: ‘I want that band.’

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Wait’1l I tell you, Paul, you don’t have to sell Seymour Stein to me. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is the man the Shangri-las phoned when they wanted to go back into the studio.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You know that all came to nothing?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Still, they phoned him. The Shangri-las. INT. FEARGAL SHARKEY’S HOUSE - DAY 109 The UNDERTONES, TERRI, MRS SHARKEY are in the sitting roo along with a serious number of holy pictures. PAUL stands off to one corner, talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Seymour? I have the band here. I’m passing you over to... MICKEY BRADLEY has been pushed forward.

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY
dialogues.text: Mickey.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Mickey.

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY
dialogues.text: (takes phone) How are you, Mr Stein? Yes, Paul has told us the offer... (listens a moment) Well, tell you the truth we’d be hoping for a bit more... (turns to look at the others who nod in encouragement ) A lot more: the same as the Rich Kids got from EMI... He pulls his head back to avoid the torrent this unleashe from the other end of the line. TERRI lets himself out of the sitting room. INT. FEARGAL SHARKEY’S HALLWAY - DAY 110 TERRI shares the hallway with a Jack Russell, which worri at his trouserleg. The sitting room door opens again. The are raised voices. MRS SHARKEY comes out with a tea tray followed by FEARGAL.  61.

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL
dialogues.text: Should you not be in there advising us?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: You boys should be advising me. The Jack Russell growls.

dialogues.speaker: FEARGAL
dialogues.text: Is that dog annoying you? (before TERRI can say anything) Sparky, stand up to be searched! Sparky adopts the position, paws spread against the wall. FEARGAL goes back into the sitting room.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Down boy. SPARKY’s tail trembles, but he keeps his paws on the wall TERRI follows FEARGAL back to the sitting room and the raised voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moorland. Rain. Only one windscreen wiper is working. Through the cleared part of the window a road sign: Airpo 45. BA scratchy version of Adam and the Ants, ‘Young Parisians’ plays. TERRI is in the back again.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I thought for a moment back there the whole thing was off. Never heard him quite so angry.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Well, you got your band, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And what about you, Terri?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: What about me?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, you recorded ‘Kicks’. It’s on your label. The tape deck cuts out. GETTY thumps the dashboard to get it going. The sun visor falls off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got the wrong idea about me. People who wouldn’t piss on me when I was hauling the record around London have been on the phone offering me twenty thousand pounds for it. I told them all to fuck off.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Twenty thousand? (with a glance at GETTY) Well, we can talk about it later.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: We can talk about it now. Getty’s as much a part of Good Vibrations as I am. They all are. There is a silence, ended by GETTY noisily changing gear.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How much did you say that van was you were looking at, Getty?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: (in the mirror) What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: The van you were looking at over the road from the shop.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: That one? Five hundred and fifty, but I’1l get him down to five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: All right then, Paul. Five hundred quid. PAUL turns in his seat to face TERRI, trying to decide if he is being serious. GETTY in the mirror is clearly wondering the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Are you sure you don’t want to talk about this later?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (rising to the occasion) Five hundred quid and a signed photo of the Shangri-las. PAUL starts to laugh. TERRI starts to laugh. GETTY continues to watch in the mirror.  114 63. EXT. AIRPORT CARPARK — DAY 112 PAUL hugs TERRI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI closes the door. GETTY starts the engine.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I thought at least you’d’ve held out for the five magic beans.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Getty, it’s very simple. If they can’t buy you they can’t own you.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: It means you and Rudi are going to be even bigger than the Undertones anyway, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: (emboldened) Fucking right.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Fucking right. He looks out the window as PAUL practically skips away. TERRI’s expression could almost be taken for doubt, but only for a second. He takes a bottle of brandy from the glove compartment. Looks out the window again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few months later. DAVE, RUTH, MARILYN, TERRI sit in a line at the bar watching a tiny black and white TV on which the UNDERTONE play ‘Get Over You’, wearing their usual skinner jeans. RUTH in particular seems subdued.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Does that make you think a wee bit of the Beach Boys?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Makes me think more of a new cistern, roof repairs, happier bank manager...  64.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: You're starting to sound like an accountant.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You're turning me into one. BRIAN walks behind them. Pauses.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Look at the state of those trousers. How come they’re on the TV and we’re not?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: You write some new songs, I’‘1l get you on. BRIAN walks off. RUTH looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I'd better be getting on here.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Hold on. He swallows as much of his pint as he can, but still abandons half. He stands, ready to leave with RUTH. At that moment a GERMAN JOURNALIST approaches with his PHOTOGRAPHER - the two of them dressed like war correspondents.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Terri Hooley?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: The Godfather of Belfast Punk? MARILYN laughs. TERRI himself looks abashed. The PHOTOGRAPHER starts taking photographs: flash, flash, fla

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN JOURNALIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We would like to make an interview with you. TERRI glances towards RUTH. She holds up her hands, resignedly, watching from the door as TERRI sits again.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN JOURNALIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So it started for you in 1977,

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no - way before that. Here (retrieves his pint) Wait till I tell you, see in the 60s... The camera continues to flash. RUTH leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. A night’s worth of cigarette smoke drifts out. GERMAN JOURNALIST and PHOTOGRAPHER emerge, blinking. TERRI brings up the rear. They walk off in opposite directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI gets off bus. The flags as before: all red, white a blue. He turns up the collar of his coat and looks about him then lights a fag and strikes out to the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI is still walking and smoking, still holding the bro paper bag. After a few more moments he stops. RUTH is walking along the street towards him. They meet.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (holding out paper bag) I brought you your lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH and TERRI look out over the city, eating sausage rol from the brown paper bag. Or at least TERRI is eating. RUTH bites a small corner off her sausage roll. TERRI watches her slowly chew.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Sorry about last night. You know me once I get started.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Why do you think I never let you get started?  66. She lets him put his arm around her. They sit in silence.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (suddenly) I’m pregnant. TERRI’s mouth opens; nothing comes out.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I’m going to be a daddy. It’s unbelievable. RUTH is still looking at him. She was hoping for more.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You remember the day we moved into the house? You told me I was everything...

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: And you didn’t want to be.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: That’s not what I said. I said...

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: You'd settle for being the most important thing.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Well from now on we’ll both have to settle for being the second most important. They sit.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Shit, I told those German fellas I'd take them to see the Pound.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I'd better be getting back to work here anyway. She brushes pastry flakes from her lap.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks for lunch. She kisses him. A bus comes. TERRI leaps up to get on.  120 121 122 67.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: We'll be absolutely fine. I’11l work twice as hard.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (as the bus doors close) Just be there. The bus with TERRI on it pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI is searching in his pocket. He pulls out his hand: there are half a dozen coppers. He stares at them a momen Shoves them back in. Searches in the other pocket, pulls out his matches. He tries to light a cigarette, but his hand shakes so much it takes him two matches. The flags on the lampposts when he looks up have changed from red, white and blue to green, white and orange. TERR sits forward in his seat. Something has caught his eye. Reflected on the windows a street protest fronted by WOME wearing only blankets, carrying pictures of young IRA men above the words ‘Political Prisoner’. OTHERS have posters saying ‘Smash H Block’. The whole thing is eerily silent. EXT. BELFAST STREET — DAY 121 A wall with a single poster for a Smash H Block rally, 3r March 1979. TERRI slaps a Harp poster over it and walks away. To an acoustic guitar accompaniment RONNIE starts to sing

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ‘Well I won’t do that, and I can’t do this, and I tell you something we hate all this...’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIAN plays guitar and RONNIE sings...

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: ‘Every time I see you, makes me realise, the pressure’s on, every single day...’ TERRI at the counter scrawls something on a piece of pape which he holds up to them: Hit!  123 124 125 126 127 68. EXT. BELFAST STREET — DAY 123 Four anti-H block posters: Rally 24th June. Four Harp posters over the top. ‘Pressure’s On’ goes electric: Brian’s solo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI gets up from seat, turns, blows his cheeks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The solo continues On one side of the glass RUDI look exhausted, but elated. On the other side DAVY SMYTH finishes writing in black fe pen the words ‘Pressure’s On - Master’ on a tape box, whi he then puts in a padded envelope, which TERRI takes from his hand and drops into his record bag. He pats DAVY’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI has the phone wedged against his shoulder, ripping open an envelope as he talks. There’s a glass of brandy beside him. The music fades.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: This is Terri Hooley (pause) Yes, that Terri Hooley. (another pause) That’s nice of you to say so. He pulls a magazine from the envelope. He’s on the cover: ‘Der “Godfather of Punk”’. He takes a drink.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've been watching your show some decent bands on. But what about putting on a really great one...? He rips the cover off the magazine. The rest of the magazine falls to the floor with a heap of other stuff fr the counter.

dialogues.speaker: GREAT VICTORIA STREET
dialogues.text: TERRI is dialling, unlit cigarette hanging from his lip. The magazine cover is on the wall now, along with Hank an the rest.  128 129 130 131 132 133 134 69. The phone is answered.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Brian? Got some good news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Smash H Block poster: rally 16th September 1977. A Harp poster slapped over the top. TERRI goes to paste up anoth one, but the whole wall is covered in the Smash H Blocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave’s workshop. TERRI watches the ‘Pressure’s On’ sleeve roll off the press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI and RUTH, heavily pregnant, on sofa. She sleeps, he rifles through a shoebox full of bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI sits at a table by the door, cashbox open beside hi Pink-haired PUNK GIRL frisks herself in an exaggerated search for money. TERRI stops the pantomime and wearily waves her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI is at the bar when he is approached by a couple of CARTOON PUNKS with a Belfast map and a camera. One after the other they pose for photos beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUDI are playing ‘The Pressure’s On’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI and the CARTOON PUNKS are capering around the livin room while Rudi play on TV and TERRI hollers along.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: ‘The pressure’s on me and you, the pressure’s on me and you.’  135 136 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH very tired-looking is on the landing, listening to t party below. She turns towards the bedroom then changes h mind and lifts the lid off the laundry basket. She climbs inside on the song’s final ‘me and you’. A beat. TERRI walks past and sets a beer can on the laund basket lid on his way to the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIAN slaps a pile of unfolded ‘Pressure’s On’ sleeves on the counter. DAVE and the other RUDI members are in attendance.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: How did you manage that?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: What are you crying about, didn’t I say I'd get you on TV?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Aye, to promote the record. Where’s the fucking record?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Did you phone the plant?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (vaguely) Those useless bastards...

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: When were you thinking of telling us there was a problem? You knew months ago we were going to be on. All you had to do was get the record out on time.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: All? (counts on his fingers) I’ve the shop, the Harp, you lot, the Outcasts, bank manager breathing down my neck... He runs out of fingers: on to the other hand.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And a wife who’s about to have a baby any day now.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: It was our big chance and you fucked it up. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to rest of RUDI) Come on to fuck out of this. They leave. TERRI grabs his coat from the back of a chair pulling the chair over in the process.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Are you going after them?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Am I fuck. I’m going to the Siouxsie gig.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: It isn’t for another six hours.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I didn’t say straight to the Siouxsie gig. He heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You not be better going home first? ‘Wife about to have a baby any day’?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH is reading a book. TV on in the background. Local early evening news. Image of a body under a sheet in the middle of the street.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREADER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The prison officer’s murder has been claimed by the IRA in retaliation for what it calls the inhuman treatment of their comrades in the Maze Prison. Loyalist paramilitaries, meantime, have threatened to step up their attacks on the Catholic population... RUTH starts up. A pain. She feels her stomach. She crosses the room and picks up the phone. 138

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAT picks up the phone.  72.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: (shouts above the music) Terri? You just missed him, love. He was here all afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: PAT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He said something about an interview. At that moment RUTH’s attention is drawn back to the TV.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREADER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Now, two years ago there were violent scenes when London punk rock band the Clash came to the Ulster Hall. Tonight the venue plays host to another London band, Siouxsie and the Banshees. Have things moved on in the interim? Our reporter David Capper is outside the hall with Belfast’s own ‘punk godfather’ Terri Hooley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI is half-cut.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I have to laugh at the great and the good when they say the punks are a menace to society. Our town was dead at night. They’ve brought life back to it. We should be thanking them instead of hassling them. These kids aren’t the problem for Belfast. These kids are the solution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH watches as TERRI gets claps on the back from the solutions to Belfast’s problems. Another stab of pain. Sh almost doubles over. Her face registers alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI stands in the wings, drinking, listening to the gig  143 144 145 146 147 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH is by the phone, clutching her stomach. She dials a number. It rings and rings and rings.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Oh, please, pick up. The phone keeps ringing and, just when she is about to despair, is picked up.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Getty? Are you not at the gig?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, I went, but I met this girl in the queue and...

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You’ve got to come and get me.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Getty, this baby’s coming. Sound of phone being dropped at the other end of the line

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After-show party in full swing: noise, LIGGERS, TERRI in the midst of them telling SIOUXSIE a story, which involve him swinging his fist. SIOUXSIE creases up laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The all-new Outcasts van speeds through the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH is hanging on, just. GETTY looks from her to the roa to her, to the road...

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Just another couple of minutes. I can see the gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI’s standing by himself, smiling, swaying.  148 149 150 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH pushes herself up on her elbows with an enormous yel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtains drawn around the bed where RUTH sits sipping a c of tea. The BABY is asleep in a hospital crib beside her. A NURSE opens curtains, a look of disapproval on her face

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Someone to see you. She steps aside. GETTY enters, shivering. If RUTH is disappointed she doesn’t let it show.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Sorry, I fell asleep in the fucking van. RUTH puts her finger to her lips. The NURSE frowns. GETTY doesn’t quite know where to put himself.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, was it all, you know, all right? RUTH leans over and pulls the crib blanket down a touch.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: A wee girl. GETTY peers in at her.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: What are you going to call her? RUTH looks at her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I was thinking Anna.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: (forgetting himself) Class! Short for Anarchy? The NURSE tugs the curtains shut. INT. ROYAL VICTORIA HOSPITAL —- DAY 150 RUTH sleeps. A moment more; a moment more. She comes awak startled. TERRI sits in a chair at the side of the bed, wearing the clothes he was wearing the night before.  75.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: How long have you been here?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You should have woken me.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Sleep when the baby sleeps, that’s what my mum says. The BABY stirs. TERRI and RUTH laugh at the coincidence. RUTH lifts her.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: She's like her mummy. She’s gorgeous.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (to BABY) This is your daddy. He’s an old charmer. (to TERRI) Do you want to hold her?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (almost recoiling) My hands are shaking too much. I'd be afraid of dropping her. RUTH tries to disguise her hurt by fussing over the baby.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s just nerves. RUTH remains focused on BABY. She’s thinking something over. And then the curtains open and GREG, FANGS and LANK PUNK tumble in. GREG holds up a bottle of cider.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Couldn’t get the champagne, Terri, but if you shake this it’ll pop to fuck. He starts to shake it. FANGS meanwhile collects glasses from the lockers of neighbouring beds. The NURSE from nig before reappears, angrier than ever.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Right, right, out, all of you. She shoves GREG, FANGS and LANKY PUNK up the ward.  76. TERRI has got to his feet. RUTH catches hold of his sleev

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you brought them with you.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Sure they’re practically family.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: But they’re not, Terri. We’re your family. (shakes her head) I can’t do this any more. I need to get out of Belfast for a while.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Out of Belfast?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: A friend of Marilyn’s has a house in Helens Bay.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: You telling me you’re leaving me?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I'm telling you everything’s different now. I love being with you, but I’m not afraid to do this on my own if I have to.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: You won’t have to. From up the ward GREG shouts.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Terri! Terri! The NURSE returns.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I need you to get those fellas off the ward this minute. The BABY is mewling. RUTH opens her nightdress to feed he

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (mumbles ) I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You do. TERRI walks up the ward. Near the end he stops and looks back at RUTH and the BABY.  151 152 153 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1960s-vintage TERRI walks through the door in mid monolog straight to camera.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I went to London, 1970, no 69, fuck it, whenever, tell the people at Oz they needed a Belfast correspondent, but they weren't interested. Two OZ STAFF in school uniform rutting on a desk. 60s TER shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the present a YOUNG FEMALE JOURNALIST holds a microphone under TERRI’s nose.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: And just when I turned to leave who comes through the door... As he says the name a TEENAGE GLASS COLLECTOR passes and mimes it in perfect sync.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: John Lennon. TERRI glances quickly over his shoulder. Takes a drink. Carries on.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And here he is to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN LENNON in white suit and long beard stands before 60 TERRI.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN LENNON
dialogues.text: Terri, what’s going on over there in Belfast, man?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Here’s me, ‘How long have you got, John?’ 60s TERRI goes into rant mode. JOHN LENNON nods, and nods then he puts his hands on TERRI’s shoulders.  154 155 156 157 158 78.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then he says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another night. TERRI, the worse for drink, stands at the bar, hands on the shoulders of a YOUNG MALE JOURNALIST, w holds his notebook like a shield as he scribbles the line TERRI delivers straight into his face.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (as Lennon) ‘I know exactly what the people there need.’ (hands off the journalist’s shoulders; himself again) I’m thinking, brilliant, a load of free records... dope!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car boot is opened to reveal a mini arsenal of guns and grenades. 60s TERRI looks up from it in horror and turns to a now crop-haired, denim-clad JOHN LENNON.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: What the fuck is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still another night. TERRI slams down a glass on the counter. No journalists now, no one but a MAN PLAYING FRU MACHINE, who nods distractedly as he pumps more money in.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I mean, what else could I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60s TERRI throws a punch that sends Imagine-era JOHN LENN sprawling against the white wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fruit machine lights flash: jackpot. MAN PLAYING FRUIT MACHINE has crouched to catch the coins that tumble out. TERRI is effectively talking to himself. He turns about, spies the phone on the wall, lifts it and dials a number.  159 79.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello? The beeps sound: TERRI has to put money in. TERRI doesn’t have the money to put in. He clicks his fingers at the MA PLAYING FRUIT MACHINE, who ignores him. The line goes dea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH replaces the receiver. She goes to the bedroom door looking in on the BABY now several-months old: fast aslee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI sits on the settee. Then curls up and tries to slee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI looks like shit. There are papers all over the counter. There are open drawers, boxes tipped out on the floor. DAVE watches from the door.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Lost something? TERRI pulls open a drawer. The bills practically fly out.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I'd a big order from Sweden the other month.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: A bit over fifteen hundred quid. (he spreads out another bundle of paper on the counter) They still haven’t paid me.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Have you not sent thema reminder? A solicitor’s letter. TERRI stops searching finally, looks at DAVE.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I think I threw out the address.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You think?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Sort of know.  80.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Fifteen hundred quid?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Actually, it might have been closer to seventeen... -fifty. DAVE at once joins in the search. He pulls out a box, roo around. Pushes it back, pulls out another.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: What’s this doing here? He turns with a padded envelope in one hand a tape box in the other. He reads the label.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘Pressure’s On Master’? TERRI grabs it with both hands then remembers himself.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (unconvincingly) That’s the back-up. DAVE shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Fuck sake, Terri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI and DAVE exit the building. A police land rover is parked at the kerb. TERRI pulls a fistful of bills from his pocket and throws them at the land rover.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Do you think if I was dealing drugs I’d have all these? The RUC MEN smirk. DAVE pulls TERRI by the sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVE and TERRI sit at a table with eight glasses on it: t empty pints, two half-drunk, two just poured, and two brandies. TERRI swallows one of the half-drunk pints, sets the glas with the other empties (both, it should now be apparent his), pulls a just-poured pint towards him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You're drinking too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave, I always drink too much. Everybody we know drinks too much.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: This is different. There’s something...

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (reaching for a brandy) Something what?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You're carrying on like one of Led Zeppelin. TERRI stares.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: That’s low. Another huge swallow of beer.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anything else you'd like to say while you’re about it?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I just think we have to try to keep things together.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Do ‘we’? And will you tell us when we can have a piss, Dave, or scratch our fucking arse? Stalinist. DAVE looks at him in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Stalinist? Your dad’s right.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: What are you talking about, ‘my dad’?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (a tremor in his voice) You took too much on because you loved the glory. You’re not a socialist at all, you’re a one- man fucking show. (each letter a finger in TERRI’s face) T-e-r-r-capital-I.  164 82. He gets up and leaves. TERRI watches him go then looks do at the table.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (half turning) You didn’t drink your brandy! He moves the glasses so that Dave’s brandy and his own ar lined up in front of him. He lifts the first.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘From each according to his ability.’ (drains glass, sets it down, raises the next) ‘To each according to his need.’ The second glass is drained. TERRI looks at his watch. He goes back up to the bar. INT. HARP BAR —- MUCH LATER 164 TERRI is still at the bar paying more attention to his pi than what’s going on behind him. A band plays. There is t usual melee on the dance-floor, but there’s an edge to it now, more aggressive. Something in the corner of the room catches TERRI’s eye. FANGS and LANKY PUNK appear to be going through a pile of coats. TERRI sets his glass down and walks over.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: You looking for something? They turn. LANKY PUNK is clearly hiding something under h jacket

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: No, it’s all right.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Because it looked to me as if you were thieving.

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: Swear to God, Terri, we weren’t. TERRI says nothing, but neither does he move. LANKY PUNK has no option. He glances round.

dialogues.speaker: LANKY PUNK
dialogues.text: I was trying to hide this He opens his jacket to reveal a gun butt. TERRI pulls the jacket shut for him.  83.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing with that?

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: It’s not real. It’s only to scare people if they try to jump HIM.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Listen, I'll give you the money for a taxi home. I’1l pay your taxis from now to Christmas, just don’t bring that fucking thing out with you again.

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: It’s not for getting home. TERRI looks at the dance-floor, his eye lighting, as thou only just noticing them, on one shaved head after another

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BANK MANAGER, sterner than he’s looked before, is delivering bad news to a clammy, hung-over TERRI.

dialogues.speaker: BANK MANAGER
dialogues.text: Your situation is really quite grave. It’s not just the over- draft - it’s the accrued interest from the original loan, it’s your tax return. I can’t stress it enough - unless something big comes up very soon you are in real danger of defaulting. Which is why I called you both here today. RUTH it is now apparent is in the room too, her seat a deliberate distance away from Terri’s. She looks at the BANK MANAGER, perplexed, then at TERRI. BANK MANAGER (CONT’D) Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH pushes open a door, walking fast. A beat then TERRI appears.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Ruth! She runs. TERRI runs too. He catches up with her as she i about to pull the gate on an antique lift. TERRI steps in  84.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: The house? She presses the button for ground floor. They are squeezed tightly together: nose to nose. Not muc more room than they would have in a bin. They start their descent.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For god's sake, Terri. Why didn’t you tell me? I believed in you. I was there every step of the way. What made you think I wouldn’t have gone along with that too?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: It was one moment. I just did it. I wasn’t thinking. I never thought. The same as with Big Time - I just did it. Same as with the tour - I just did it. The Harp, Teenage Kicks - I just did it. It’s how I operate. It’s who I am. And you know what - I haven’t done too badly.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Open your eye, Terri. The lift shudders to a halt: ground floor RUTH pulls open the door and walks out. TERRI is left contemplating the full-length mirror she was standing in front of: he’s an absolute mess. The lift starts going down. No floors below ‘ground’, but still it goes down, and down, darker and darker. TERRI stares at his reflection. Grotesque.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI sits alone staring at the picture of him from the magazine, or it stares at him. Sonny Bono, ‘Laugh At Me’ the record player. He is shitfaced. A noise. He looks up. MUTT and HATCHET stand there.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: We saw your light on.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I thought I told you were barred.  85. MUTT ignores him. HATCHET is picking up records, looking them, and tossing them over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go, on, fuck off, find a couple of old ladies to frighten.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: You're very funny. Isn’t he, Hatchet? Isn’t he very funny? HATCHET grunts.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Actually, this is a business call. Me and Hatchet’s in a band now. Aren’t we Hatchet? HATCHET grunts again.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tight wee unit. HATCHET sniggers.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck sake, Hatchet, behave. (to TERRI) Thought you might be interested in our demo tape. We were going to call it ‘The Only Good Wog’s a Dead Wog’, then we thought ‘The Only Good Taig’, but then we thought ‘The Only Good One’s a Dead One’ covered pretty much everything.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I’d sooner sell bog rolls than Nazi shite like that. For all his bravado, he is scared here. He is edging as h speaks - and as well as someone so shitfaced can edge - towards the door. HATCHET bars the way.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: You’1l sell what I tell you to sell. I’m used to getting my own way. Ask the fellas you used to say would put me to bed. He sticks the head in TERRI. HATCHET weighs in. A flurry kicks and punches. When it is finished MUTT leans over TERRI.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You made such a big deal about not letting me in here. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MUTT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And look at it. It’s fuck all. You're fuck all. You fucking lost. HATCHET pulls a record rack over on top of TERRI, who hasn't moved since the beating ended. MUTT leaves; HATCHET delivers a final kick to the head. INT. TERRI’S WORLD - NIGHT AND DAY JUMBLED TOGETHER 169 The music is distorted becoming the soundtrack as HATCHET kick to the head takes us - as in scene 2 - on an accelerated journey into Terri’s world, not the future th time, but the past, a collapsing together of many of the moments that have made up the film, as far back as CHILD TERRI, with his turntable, sticking his head above the hedge, interspersed with lights and looming faces - DOCTO GEORGE, MAVIS - and a single word, repeated:

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Open your eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Open your eye. Black, a moment more. MAVIS (0.S.) (CONT’D) Very funny. The other one. TERRI opens his seeing eye. MAVIS stands before him, a bottle of surgical spirit and a wad of cotton wool in her hand. TERRI is seated at the table, on the mend, but still battered-looking.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That must have been some door? What was it, a car ferry? MAVIS ministers to a few more of his bruises and abrasion MAVIS (CONT’D) I don’t suppose there’s any point me mentioning the police.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: They’d want to buy the door a drink.  171 87. MAVIS has tilted his face up and is looking into it.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I never knew a wee boy as bad at keeping his head out of harm’s way. People used to tell me I was lucky, girls were the hard ones to raise. You caused me more anxiety growing up than a whole hockey team.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Well I'd like to meet this hockey team to discuss it... MAVIS bats him, absentmindedly. TERRI winces.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: You’re a married man. (beat) Supposed to be. Suddenly irritated she goes to the window. She raps the glass. Hard. MAVIS (CONT’D) Where is that man? I told him ten minutes ago his tea was ready. It’ll be stone cold. TERRI gets up takes the cup from the countertop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back garden: small but ingeniously planted for maximu yield and colour. GEORGE straightens from a flowerbed as TERRI approaches. They sit on a small bench.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Garden's looking well.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That’s what all the dirty work in winter’s for. TERRI looks down at the mug. He’s almost forgotten he was holding it.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Did your mother send you out with that?  172 88.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I thought I better offer before she put the window in. She was getting herself worked up about me and Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She has very strong views on marriage. She wouldn’t have stayed with me all these years otherwise. They sit on a small bench.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember that dig you had at me about all those elections

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Da, I’m sorry...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It wasn’t ten, it was twelve. The returning officer used to say if I was a horse they’d have shot me after the sixth. But do you know what? I have friends and comrades living all over his city. And do you know what else? In every election I increased my vote. TERRI’s gaze is locked on his father’s face. He looks as though he might hug GEORGE, but GEORGE, unaware of this ( perhaps not so) chooses this moment to empty his tea leav on to the flowerbed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Victory doesn’t always look the way other people imagine it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUDI members slouch against the wall nearest the door. DA stands only a few feet further in, arms folded tight. TERRI at moments in this scene is picking things up off t floor, the counter: a physical counterpart to his verbal attempts to set things straight.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: All right. A few apologies are in order. RUDI and DAVE look like they agree.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Brian, you want to start?  89. Expectation turns to confusion on BRIAN’s face.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m only messing you. (beat) Dave? DAVE opens his mouth to protest. TERRI doesn’t let him.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen, I'll hold my hand up, I’ve taken my eye off the ball, but we haven’t time for arguing. It’s time to focus. We’ve a gig to organise.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: A gig?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: A Good Vibrations gig.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: A fundraiser?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Yeah, a fundraiser.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: No harm to you, Terri, but unless you're charging a hundred quid a head I think it’s maybe gone beyond a night at the Harp.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Who said anything about the Harp?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: The Pound then... (TERRI is smiling: not the Pound either) The Students’ Union?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Try ‘Ulster Hall’.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Ulster Hall?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Because the Ulster Hall holds two thousand people.  173 174 90.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I know how many it holds, I've been in it often enough. DAVE takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: OK, OK, we call in favours - we get Siouxsie back to headline. Fuck it, we call the Clash, Stiff Little Fingers...

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Fucking showbands. We don’t need them. It’s a Good Vibrations gig, it’1l be Good Vibrations bands.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (whispering) Terri, we're talking two thousand people. Be realistic.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: What, like you were realistic when you brought me round this place? As he speaks, the record racks disappear. DAVE and TERRI stand in the derelict building. They look at one another. A beat. And they have returned to GOOD VIBRATIONS. TERRI still setting things straight - pulls the German magazine cover from the wall.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: How many posters do you think you'll need? EXT. BELFAST STREETS — DAY 173 BRIAN is postering. GREG is postering; so too FANGS, GETT RONNIE, LANKY PUNK, and TERRI of course. He stands before a wall with NF and SHANKILL SKINS scrawl on it. He slaps a poster over the top. ‘Outcasts. Moondog Ruefrex, Rudi, Big Self,’ it reads, ‘24th April 1980, Ulster Hall.’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH is pushing a buggy. She passes a wall with Good Vibrations posters. She stops. Looks. The posters have be pasted up in such a way that they spell out the word LIVE  175 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand flicks a light switch, then another, then another, and another. One by one the lights come up on the Ulster Hall. Which is empty. TERRI stands on the edge of the stage. He looks worried. DAVE walks out behind him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Where the fuck is everyone?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: It‘ll be all right. They’1l come.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: We've hardly sold a ticket. RONNIE has wandered on stage. He sings into the microphon to the tune of ‘Pressure’s On’, and mostly tongue in chee

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: (tongue in cheek, mostly) Well you fucked up that, and you fucked up this, so fuck knows, Terri, why we’re doing this... A door opens at the far end of the hall. A balding, beard figure in a blazer comes walking towards them. TERRI and DAVE peer at him, looks of recognition and disbelief. RONNIE has spotted the figure now as well.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s John fucking Peel. TERRI and DAVE get down from the stage.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PEEL
dialogues.text: Always nice to get the full name.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you came.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PEEL
dialogues.text: You gave me the best two minutes and twenty-eight seconds of my life, how could I not come? I’m just glad I got here in one piece.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Rough journey?  92.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PEEL
dialogues.text: Oh, no, the flight was fine. I mean getting through the doors of this place. (seeing TERRI and DAVE’S blank looks) You mean you haven’t had a look out the front?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI, DAVE, and JOHN PEEL at an upstairs window look dow on a street thronged with PUNKS and overstretched RUC MEN

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Didn't I tell you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (finding the cloud in the silver lining) Fuck, I hope they’re going to let this go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trickle of PUNKS is being let in. The combined might of the DOOR STAFF and the RUC can barely hold back those sti outside. TERRI remonstrates with FRONT OF HOUSE MANAGER.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Can you not just throw the doors open?

dialogues.speaker: FRONT OF HOUSE MANAGER
dialogues.text: I'd be within my rights to shut them altogether. Half of them are full drunk and the other half are trying to run in without paying. FANGS forces his way to the fore of the crowd at the door

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: Terri! An RUC MAN pushes him back with a hand in the face.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Hold on. He’s on the guest-list. (to Fangs) Come on, move your arse.

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: What about my mates?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Hurry up.  178 179 93. TERRI waves them through too: about a dozen in all. Hands shoot up here there and everywhere at the doors.

dialogues.speaker: PUNKS
dialogues.text: Terri! Terri! Am I on the list? TERRI looks at the FRONT OF HOUSE MANAGER; he looks at th BOX OFFICE STAFF, waiting by their tills. He looks back a the doors, the RUC MEN, the waving hands of PUNKS outside

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (shouts ) Don’t worry, you'll all get in. The FRONT OF HOUSE MANAGER walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds of Ruefrex from the stage. RONNIE watches in the wings. BRIAN practices licks on his unplugged guitar. Nearby JOHN PEEL talks to GETTY, whose interest is torn between PEEL and Pink-haired PUNK GIRL across the room.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PEEL
dialogues.text: What amazes me is that punk has more or less died out everywhere else...

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: You around after the show, John? (heading for the girl) I‘1l buy you a pint.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PEEL
dialogues.text: (to thin air.) Yeah, buy me a pint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The logjam at the doors has been broken. A few PUNKS are showing tickets at the box office. Many more are walking straight in, past the RUC MEN, past TERRI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUDI leave the stage, elated. GREG waits to go on.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Cheers for warming them up. RONNIE scowls. The hall is so full now there are PUNKS on stage. There a RUC MEN too in the shadows at the very back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To a huge ovation, JOHN PEEL appears and eventually speak

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PEEL
dialogues.text: You're a good audience. People always say Belfast is the best audience. And now here’s your best band - the Outcasts. OUTCASTS come running on.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Right, this one’s for everybody's favourite people in the world. Rudi’s already give you a song about them. This one’s called ‘The Bastards are Coming’. They launch into ‘The Cops are Coming’ and JOHN PEEL is right, they do sound finally like the best band in Belfas PUNKS on stage bait the RUC who do nothing; nothing at al

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘The Cops are Coming’ is thudding through the walls. DAVE and FRONT OF HOUSE MANAGER are deep in conversation. Neither looks happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OUTCASTS are finishing ‘Self-Conscious Over You’. GETTY’s shirt is off; GREG’s grin is broader than ever.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: And now I'd like to welcome on stage the man who made all this possible... TERRI’s name is lost in the roar as he walks out from the wings ‘OUTCASTS’ across the back of his leather jacket. FANGS grabs the mike from GREG.

dialogues.speaker: FANGS
dialogues.text: Terri is our leader, Terri is our leader, na-na-na-na... TERRI takes the mike from him. He is barely audible above the stomping and whistling.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: No leaders! No godfathers! A kind of quiet returns. TERRI breathes deeply, scanning the faces.  95.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming. When I look out at you all gathered here it confirms something that I’ve always felt: New York has the haircuts, London has the trousers, but Belfast has the reason. Good Vibrations isn’t a record shop, it isn’t a label, it’s a way of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tumult out front. TERRI runs offstage triumphant. DAVE is waiting for him, fuming.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Isn’t it incredible.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: It’s fucking unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (oblivious) The best night ever.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Terri, we’ve made a loss. We’ve packed out the Ulster Hall and we've somehow made a fucking loss. Your man at the front says you had the longest guest list in the hall’s entire history, longer than all the other guest lists put together. And all of it apparently carried in your head. He has been getting closer and closer to TERRI. His hands suddenly shoot out and grab TERRI by the throat.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Terri, the whole point of tonight was to raise money.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: (trying to prise open Dave's fingers) No, Dave, it wasn’t. Not the whole point. Money couldn't buy what we’ve just done. He finally succeeds in loosening Dave’s grip. Gasps.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We've taken back Belfast tonight.  184 96. The chanting is getting louder. Terri’s name. DAVE finall hears it. With a flash of the OUTCASTS on his jacket, TER goes to run back on stage and runs straight into RUTH. She's heard everything.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You and your guest lists. TERRI looks shamefaced.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: About what? The house? Sure it’s only bricks. The chanting from the crowd is louder still.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're wanted. (jabs a finger into his chest) But you still owe me forty quid. She walks away. TERRI goes to speak, but there is nothing to say. He runs on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUDI and the other bands have joined the OUTCASTS on stag

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: We're all going to do an old Sonny Bono number, because we fucking can. And they fucking play ‘Laugh at me’:

dialogues.speaker: TERRI/OUTCASTS/RUDI
dialogues.text: Why can’t I be like any guy, why do they try to make me run, son of a gun now, what do they care about the clothes I wear, why get their kicks from making fun... TERRI’s eye lights on RUTH, dancing on her own.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI/OUTCASTS/RUDI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This world’s got a lot of space and if they don’t like my face it ain’t me that’s going anywhere, no. So I don’t care, then laugh at me, if that’s the fare I have to pay to be free...  97. GREG drapes an arm around TERRI. TERRI glances to his rig and instead of GREG it’s HANK WILLIAMS, his rhinestone su replaced by a studded jacket. TERRI carries on singing.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI/OUTCASTS/RUDI... HANK
dialogues.text: Then laugh at me, and I'll cry for you and I'll pray for you and I‘1l do all the things that the man upstairs says to do, I’1l do them I’1l1 do them all for you... TERRI looks at HANK, who nods. TERRI dives on to the outstretched arms.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTION
dialogues.text: Good Vibrations closed in 1982 Reopened in 1984 Closed in 1991 Reopened in 1992 Closed in 2002 Reopened in 2004 Terri still hasn’t had his signed photo of the Shangri-las.
